etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, from late Latin excitatio(n-), from excitare ‘rouse, call forth’ (see excite)

definitions: the application of energy to a particle, object, or physical system.
the process in which an atom or other particle adopts a higher energy state when energy is supplied
shortDefinitions: process in which particle adopts higher energy state

definitions: the state of enhanced activity or potential activity of a cell, organism, or tissue that results from its stimulation

examples.text: these neurotransmitters can produce excitation or inhibition

definitions: the process of applying current to the winding of an electromagnet to produce a magnetic field

examples.text: continuous rotation of the motor by sequential excitation of the phase windings
two parallel coils with opposing excitation windings

definitions: the process of applying a signal voltage to the control electrode of an electron tube or the base of a transistor.
the action or state of exciting or being excited; excitement
